tit.e: Oyatoi-gaikokujin (foreigners in Japan hired to teach new techniques)
tit.cmt: "Hired foreigners" is essentially a meaningless phrase.
tit.e: Oyatoi-gaikokujin (foreigners in Japan hired to teach new techniques)

sen.j: お雇い（御雇）外国人（おやといがいこくじん）とは、幕末以降明治初期に、「殖産興業」などを目的として、欧米の先進技術や学問、制度を輸入するために雇用された欧米人のことである。
sen.e: Oyatoi-gaikokujin (hired foreigners) refers to European and American people who were hired for the purpose of importing the advanced technology, scholarship and systems of Europe and America to Japan under the name of 'Shokusan-kogyo' (encouragement of production and industry) from the end of the Edo period to the early Meiji period.

The term "oyatoi-gaikokujin" refers to the practice, common from the late Edo period into the early Meiji period, of hiring Europeans and Americans to foster the importation into Japan of the advanced technologies, scholarship and systems of Europe and the United States under the banner of 'Shokusan-kogyo' (encouragement of production and industry).

The term "oyatoi-gaikokujin" refers to the practice, common from the late Edo period into the early Meiji period, of hiring Europeans and Americans to foster the importation into Japan of the advanced technologies, scholarship and systems of Europe and the United States under the banner of 'Shokusan-kogyo' (encouragement of production and industry).

sen.j: 江戸幕府や各藩、明治以降は新政府や各府県、または民間によって招聘された。
sen.e: They were invited by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and regional domains; after the Meiji period, they were invited by the new Meiji government, the prefectural offices, or by the private sectors.

Such foreigners were invited to Japan by the Edo bakufu (shogunate) and by various regional domains; beginning in the Meiji period, they were invited by the new Meiji government, prefectural offices, or by the private sector.

Such foreigners were invited to Japan by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and by various regional domains; beginning in the Meiji period, they were invited by the new Meiji government, prefectural offices, or by the private sector.
sen.cmt: 「江戸幕府」のカッコ部分を修正しました。（用語統一）

sen.j: 幕末に各藩が競って外国人を抱えて雇用したために、お抱え外国人ともよばれることもある。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period, the regional domains competed to hire the foreigners in ordinary to the lords; as such, they were also called Okakae-gaikokujin (foreigners in service).
In the final years of the Edo period, each domain competed in the hiring of foreigners to serve their lords; as such, they were also called Okakae-gaikokujin (foreigners in service).
In the final years of the Edo period, each domain competed in the hiring of foreigners to serve their lords; as such, they were also called Okakae-gaikokujin (foreigners in service).

sen.j: 広義では在外公館で雇用されていた者や、外国人居留地の警備に当たった者なども含まれるが、本項では日本が欧米から新しい技術や知識を学ぶために雇用した人物について述べる。
sen.e: Although Oyatoi-gaikokujin also included employees at foreign diplomatic missions as well as those who guarded the residential areas for foreigners, the present section describes the people who were employed by the Japanese government for the purpose of learning new technology and scholarship from Europe and America.

Although broadly speaking the designation oyatoi-gaikokujin also included the employees of foreign diplomatic missions in Japan as well as the (foreign) guards at the foreign settlements, for the purposes of this article the term will be used only for those foreigners who were employed by the Japanese government in order to foster the learning of new technologies and scholarship from Europe and the United States.

Although broadly speaking the designation oyatoi-gaikokujin also included the employees of foreign diplomatic missions in Japan as well as the (foreign) guards at the foreign settlements, for the purposes of this article the term will be used only for those foreigners who were employed by the Japanese government in order to foster the learning of new technologies and scholarship from Europe and the United States.

sen.j: 概要
sen.cmt: Overview→Summary と修正しました。（用語統一）

sen.j: お雇い外国人は、日本の近代化の過程で西欧の先進技術や知識を学ぶために雇用された。
sen.e: Oyatoi-gaikokujin were employed for the purpose of learning the advanced technology and scholarship from Europe and America in the process of Japan's modernization.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Oyatoi-gaikokujin were employed to teach native Japanese the latest technologies and knowledge from Europe and the United States in order to fuel the process of Japan's modernization.
Oyatoi-gaikokujin were employed to teach native Japanese the latest technologies and knowledge from Europe and the United States in order to fuel the process of Japan's modernization.

sen.j: 彼らは産・官・学の様々な分野で後世に及ぶ影響を残した。
sen.e: Their influence on the various fields including industry, politics and scholarship extended to the later generations.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: These foreigners would have a lasting influence on various fields, including industry, politics and academia, for generations thereafter.
These foreigners would have a lasting influence on various fields, including industry, politics and academia, for generations thereafter.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期からヤン・ヨーステンやウィリアム・アダムスなどの例があり、幕府の外交顧問や技術顧問を務め徳川家康の評価を得て厚遇されたほか、後にはフィリップ・フランツ・フォン・シーボルトなども一時期幕府顧問になったという経緯もある。
sen.e: Since the early Edo period, there were hired foreigners such as Jan JOOSTEN and William ADAMS who were appreciated and were treated well by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who valued them as advisers on foreign diplomacy or technology for bakufu, as well as Philipp Franz Balthasar von SIEBOLD who were an adviser for bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: From the early days of the Edo period, there had been foreigners hired for this purpose in Japan, notably Jan JOOSTEN and William ADAMS, both highly esteemed and well treated by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who valued them as advisers to the bakufu on foreign diplomacy or technology; there was also the example of Philipp Franz Balthasar von SIEBOLD, who was employed briefly as an adviser for the bakufu.
sen.cmt: Most native Japanese translators consistently drop the definite article for words like "bakufu", but it is absolutely necessary.
sen.e: From the early days of the Edo period, there had been foreigners hired for this purpose in Japan, notably Jan JOOSTEN and William ADAMS, both highly esteemed and well treated by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who valued them as advisers to the bakufu on foreign diplomacy or technology; there was also the example of Philipp Franz Balthasar von SIEBOLD, who was employed briefly as an adviser for the bakufu.

sen.j: しかし外国人の雇用が本格化するのは鎖国が解かれ先進海外に範を求めるようになった明治維新以降である。
sen.e: However, it was after the Meiji Restoration that the Japanese government started to hire foreigners on a full-scale during which the country marked the end of the long period of isolation and looked for models abroad.

However, it was not until after the Meiji Restoration, which saw the end of the long period of national isolation and the beginning of Japan's search for models abroad, that the Japanese government began the full-scale hiring of foreigners.

However, it was not until after the Meiji Restoration, which saw the end of the long period of national isolation and the beginning of Japan's search for models abroad, that the Japanese government began the full-scale hiring of foreigners.

sen.j: 幕末の1855年、徳川幕府は長崎に海軍伝習所を開設し、オランダからカッテンディーケらを招き軍事顧問とした。
sen.e: In 1855, the Tokugawa shogunate established a Japanese Naval School in Nagasaki and invited the Dutch people such as Willem Huyssen van KATTENDIJKE as advisers on military affairs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: In 1855, the Tokugawa shogunate established a Japanese Naval School in Nagasaki and invited several Dutchmen, notably Willem Huyssen van KATTENDIJKE, to serve as advisers on military affairs.

In 1855 of the end of Edo Period, the Tokugawa shogunate established a Japanese Naval School in Nagasaki and invited several Dutchmen, notably Willem Huyssen van KATTENDIJKE, to serve as advisers on military affairs.

sen.j: そのため海軍の黎明期にはオランダ人が指導の中心となったが、明治新政府に替わってからはイギリス人を顧問に据えることでイギリスに習った海軍運営となった。
sen.e: As such, in the early days of Japanese Navy, the Dutch people led the training; however, since the new Meiji government started, the English people were employed as advisers, and as such, the management of the Navy followed the English example.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: As a consequence, in the early days of the Japanese Navy it was primarily Dutchmen who led the way; with the birth of the new Meiji government, however, Englishmen were employed as advisers, and as such, the administration of the Navy followed the British model.

As a consequence, in the early days of the Japanese Navy it was primarily Dutchmen who led the way; with the birth of the new Meiji government, however, Englishmen were employed as advisers, and as such, the administration of the Navy followed the British model.

sen.j: 陸軍の系譜においては、幕府ではフランスから軍事顧問を招いていた。
sen.e: In terms of the development of the Army, the bakufu used to invite the military advisers from France.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: As regards the developmental pedigree of the Japanese Army, under the bakufu military advisers were invited from France.
As regards the developmental pedigree of the Japanese Army, under the bakufu military advisers were invited from France.

sen.j: しかし顧問団が戊辰戦争で箱館戦争し敗戦の結果に終わり、ヨーロッパで普仏戦争にプロイセン（ドイツ）が勝利したこともあってか、明治新政府は軍制を転換しドイツから顧問団を招くこととした。
sen.e: However, as the advisory group lost their battle at Hakodate during the Boshin War, and perhaps also because Prussia (Germany) won the Franco-Prussian War, the new Meiji government changed its military system and decided to invite advisory group from Germany.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: However, because the efforts of this advisory group ended in defeat at the battle of Hakodate during the Boshin War, and perhaps also because Prussia (Germany) won the Franco-Prussian War, the new Meiji government overturned its military system and decided to invite an advisory group from Germany.
sen.cmt: Phrasing, word choice, overly free translation
sen.e: However, because the efforts of this advisory group ended in defeat at the battle of Hakodate during the Boshin War, and perhaps also because Prussia (Germany) won the Franco-Prussian War, the new Meiji government overturned its military system and decided to invite an advisory group from Germany.

sen.j: 北海道開拓関係ではアメリカ合衆国人が多く招かれた。
sen.e: For the project of reclaiming Hokkaido, many people from the United States of America were invited.
As regards the project of reclaiming the land of Hokkaido, most people invited to participate were from the United States of America.
As regards the project of reclaiming the land of Hokkaido, most people invited to participate were from the United States of America.

sen.j: 幕末までに勃興したオランダ人は、維新後は土木の河川技術方面でヨハニス・デ・レーケ等多くの人材が雇用された（オランダの治水技術が関係者に高く評価された背景があるとされているが、アントニウス・ボードウィン博士兄弟との縁故による斡旋という説もある）。
sen.e: The Dutch people rose to influential positions by the end of the Edo period, and people such as Johannis de RIJKE were hired for the field of river engineering (it is said that this was because Dutch flood control technology was highly praised by those who were involved; however, there is also a theory that this was because of the nepotism practiced by Dr. Anthonius Franciscus BAUDUIN and his younger brother).

The Dutch had risen to influential positions by the end of the Edo period, and after the Restoration many Dutchmen, notably Johannis de RIJKE, were hired in the field of river engineering (it is said that this was because Dutch flood control technology was highly praised by those connected to this field of engineering; however, a different theory holds that the large-scale hiring of Dutch river engineers was due to the nepotism of Dr. Anthonius Franciscus BAUDUIN and his younger brother).

The Dutch had risen to influential positions by the end of the Edo period, and after the Restoration many Dutchmen, notably Johannis de RIJKE, were hired in the field of river engineering (It is said that this was because Dutch flood control technology was highly praised by those connected to this field of engineering; however, a different theory holds that the large-scale hiring of Dutch river engineers was due to the nepotism of Dr. Anthonius Franciscus BAUDUIN and his younger brother.)
sen.cmt: カッコ内の始まり、ピリオドの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: 工部美術学校ではイタリア人が雇用された。
sen.e: For the schools of arts and technologies, Italian people were employed.
Italians were employed at schools for craftsmanship and art.
Italians were employed at schools for craftsmanship and art.

sen.j: 【参考】『資料 御雇外国人』（1975）には1868（明治1年）から1889年（明治22年）までに日本の公的機関・私的機関・個人が雇用した外国籍の者の数として2,299人の名前が挙げられている（注：家族や在外公館の雇用者も含む）。
sen.e: Reference: In "Shiryo: Oyatoi-gaikokujin"(Document: Hired Foreigners) (1975), there are names of 2,299 people with foreign nationalities who were employed by Japanese public and private institutions as well as by individuals between 1868 and 1889 (the list includes the names of families and employees at the foreign diplomatic missions).

Reference: The 1975 document entitled "Shiryo: Oyatoi-gaikokujin"(Document on Hired Foreigners) lists the names of 2,299 people with foreign nationalities who were employed by Japanese public and private institutions as well as by individuals between 1868 and 1889 (the list includes the names of families and employees at the foreign diplomatic missions).

Reference: The 1975 document entitled "Shiryo: Oyatoi-gaikokujin"(Document on Hired Foreigners) lists the names of 2,299 people with foreign nationalities who were employed by Japanese public and private institutions as well as by individuals between 1868 and 1889 (the list includes the names of families and employees at the foreign diplomatic missions).

sen.j: 内訳はイギリス人928人、アメリカ人374人、フランス人259人、中国人253人、ドイツ人175人、オランダ人87人などである。
sen.e: The breakdown is; 928 English; 374 Americans, 259 French, 253 Chinese, 175 Germans, 87 Dutch and others.
The breakdown by nationality is 928 Englishmen, 374 Americans, 259 Frenchmen, 253 Chinese, 175 Germans, 87 Dutch, and several others of various nationalities.
sen.cmt: Minor phrasing, confusing and inadequate "and others" translation for "nado".
sen.e: The breakdown by nationality is 928 Englishmen, 374 Americans, 259 Frenchmen, 253 Chinese, 175 Germans, 87 Dutch, and several others of various nationalities.

sen.j: お雇い外国人は高額な報酬で雇用されたことが知られる。
sen.e: It is known that Oyatoi-gaikokujin received high payments.
It is well-known that Oyatoi-gaikokujin were highly paid.
It is well-known that Oyatoi-gaikokujin were highly paid.

sen.j: 政府首脳の月俸が数百円の時代、外国人で数百円から千円を越えるものもいた。
sen.e: During the era in which the top-level ministers at the government received several hundred yen monthly, these foreigners received monthly wage ranging between several hundred yen to over one thousand.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: During an era in which the top-level ministers in the government were being paid monthly salaries of a few hundred yen, foreigners were being paid a monthly wage that ranged between several hundred yen to over one thousand.

During an era in which the top-level ministers in the government were being paid monthly salaries of a few hundred yen, foreigners were being paid a monthly wage that ranged between several hundred yen to over one thousand.

sen.j: これは身分格差が著しい当時の国内賃金水準からしても極めて高額であった。
sen.e: This was extremely high salary even in comparison to the national standard of wages in the era when the difference between the social ranks was great.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Even compared to national wage levels in an era when the status difference between social classes was very large, such a salary was extremely high.
Even compared to national wage levels in an era when the status difference between social classes was very large, such a salary was extremely high.

sen.j: 国際的に極度の円安状況だったこともあるが、当時の欧米からすれば日本は極東の辺境であり、外国人身辺の危険も少なくなかったことから、一流の技術や知識の専門家を招聘することが困難だったことによる。
sen.e: This was partly because of the situation in which yen was extremely weak internationally, but it was mainly because of the difficulty in inviting top-class technicians and experts to Japan which was far-eastern outpost and where there was a considerable physical danger for foreigners.

The high salaries were partly due to the fact that the yen was extremely weak internationally, but mainly because of the difficulty in convincing top-class experts in technology and knowledge to come to Japan, which from the perspective of Westerners was a country on the extreme eastern edge of the Far East, a country moreover that held considerable physical danger for foreigners.

The high salaries were partly due to the fact that the yen was extremely weak internationally, but mainly because of the difficulty in convincing top-class experts in technology and knowledge to come to Japan, which from the perspective of Westerners was a country on the extreme eastern edge of the Far East, a country moreover that held considerable physical danger for foreigners.

sen.j: 所期の任務を終えるとそのほとんどは帰国した。
sen.e: Most foreigners went back to their own countries when they completed their terms of office.
The vast majority of foreigners returned to their own countries upon completing the tasks for which they had been hired.
The vast majority of foreigners returned to their own countries upon completing the tasks for which they had been hired.

sen.j: お雇い外国人のなかにはトーマス・ウォートルスのように一山当てようとやってきた流れ者や、チャールズ＝デ・ボアンヴィルのように傲慢で日本人を軽視する者もいたが、他方では日本を深く愛し弟子たちに慕われた人物もいる。
sen.e: Although there were some Oyatoi-gaikokujin such as Thomas James WALTERS, a drifter who came to Japan thinking to strike oil or Charles Alfred Chastel de BOINVILLE who arrogantly disdained Japanese people, there were others who appreciated Japan deeply and were loved by their disciples.

Although there were some Oyatoi-gaikokujin who looked down on the Japanese, notably Thomas James WALTERS, a drifter who came to Japan thinking to strike it rich, or the arrogant Charles Alfred Chastel de BOINVILLE, there were many others who deeply appreciated Japan and were greatly respected by their (Japanese) disciples.

Although there were some Oyatoi-gaikokujin who were drifters who came to Japan thinking to strike it rich, notably Thomas James WALTERS, or arrogant and looked down on the Japanese such as Charles Alfred Chastel de BOINVILLE, there were many others who deeply appreciated Japan and were greatly respected by their (Japanese) disciples.
sen.cmt: 文脈に応じて、オーダーを修正しました。

sen.j: 小泉八雲やジョサイア・コンドル、エドウィン・ダンのように日本文化に惹かれて滞在し続け、日本で生涯を終えた人物もいる。
sen.e: There were those such as Yakumo KOIZUMI, Josiah CONDOR and Edwin Conder who were attracted to Japanese culture, and stayed and died in Japan.
There were those such as Yakumo KOIZUMI (Lafcadio Hearn), Josiah CONDOR and Edwin Conder who found themselves captivated by Japanese culture, and chose to remain in Japan for the rest of their lives.
There were those such as Yakumo KOIZUMI (Lafcadio Hearn), Josiah CONDOR and Edwin DUN who found themselves captivated by Japanese culture, and chose to remain in Japan for the rest of their lives.
sen.cmt: Edwin Conder→Edwin DUN と修正しました。

sen.j: 墓所
お雇い外国人の中には日本に墓所が残されている者もいる。
sen.e: Some of Oyatoi-gaikokujin were buried in Japanese graveyards.
Some Oyatoi-gaikokujin were buried in graveyards in Japan.
Some Oyatoi-gaikokujin were buried in graveyards in Japan.

sen.j: 小泉八雲は島根県松江市の重要な観光資源にも位置付けられている。
sen.e: The grave of Yakumo KOIZUMI is considered as the important tourist resource for Matsue City in Shimane Prefecture.
The grave of Yakumo KOIZUMI (Lafcadio Hearn) is treated as a major tourist attraction for the city of Matsue in Shimane Prefecture.
The grave of Yakumo KOIZUMI (Lafcadio Hearn) is treated as a major tourist attraction for the city of Matsue in Shimane Prefecture.

sen.j: フェノロサはロンドン滞在中に亡くなったが、園城寺（三井寺）に埋葬された。
sen.e: Fenollosa, who died in London, was laid to rest in Onjo-ji Temple (Mii-dera Temple).
Although Fenollosa died in London, he was laid to rest in Onjo-ji Temple (also known as Mii-dera Temple).
Although Fenollosa died in London, he was laid to rest in Onjo-ji Temple (also known as Mii-dera Temple).

sen.j: 東京都にある青山霊園の青山外国人墓地では、関係者の所在が不明となり、管理料（2005年現在、年590円）が長年にわたって未納のままのものがある。
sen.e: In the graveyard for the foreign residents in Aoyama Cemetery in Tokyo, there are graves of foreigners whose relatives can no longer be traced and the maintenance fee (590 yen yearly as of 2005) has not been collected for many years.

In Aoyama Cemetery, a graveyard for foreign residents in Tokyo, some of the graves are of foreigners who no longer have any known relatives, as a consequence of which the maintenance fee (590 yen yearly as of 2005) has not been paid for many years.

In Aoyama Cemetery, a graveyard for foreign residents in Tokyo, some of the graves are of foreigners who no longer have any known relatives, as a consequence of which the maintenance fee (590 yen yearly as of 2005) has not been paid for many years.

sen.j: 通例であれば無縁仏として集合墳墓に改葬されるところだが、青山霊園の場合、2006年度に東京都側が78基にのぼる管理費滞納お雇い外国人墓所を文化史的に再評価し、史跡として保護する方針であることが2005年2月18日の読売新聞で報じられた。
sen.e: In such a case, the remains are usually reburied in a collective graveyard as muen botoke (a person who died leaving nobody to look after his/her grave); however, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government re-evaluated 78 graves of Oyatoi-gaikokujin for which maintenance fee has been unpaid as important in terms of cultural history, and it plans to preserve them as the historical site, as reported by the Yomiuri Shimbun on February 18, 2005.

In such cases, the remains are usually reclassified as muen botoke (a person who has died leaving nobody to look after his or her grave) and reburied in a communal grave; but in the fiscal year of 2006, as reported by the Yomiuri Shimbun (the Daily Yomiuri) on February 18, 2005, in the case of the Aoyama Cemetery the Tokyo Metropolitan Government re-evaluated 78 graves of Oyatoi-gaikokujin for which the maintenance fee has not been paid as important from the perspective of cultural history, and it plans to preserve them as historical sites.

In such cases, the remains are usually reclassified as muen botoke (a person who has died leaving nobody to look after his or her grave) and reburied in a communal grave; but in the fiscal year of 2006, as reported by the Yomiuri Shimbun (the Daily Yomiuri) on February 18, 2005, in the case of the Aoyama Cemetery the Tokyo Metropolitan Government re-evaluated 78 graves of Oyatoi-gaikokujin for which the maintenance fee has not been paid as important from the perspective of cultural history, and it plans to preserve them as historical sites.

sen.j: 学術・教育
sen.e: Foreigners employeed in the fields of Scholarship and Education
Foreigners employeed in the fields of Scholarship and Education

sen.j: 小泉八雲
sen.e: Yakumo KOIZUMI (British, also known as Lafcadio Hearn)
sen.cmt: I strongly recommend including the note on nationality in the original name line, as it is very confusing to have it after the area of speciality (for example, saying "philosophy" (Russian) sounds like the person specialized in Russian philosophy, not that he was Russian himself).
sen.e: Yakumo KOIZUMI (British, also known as Lafcadio Hearn)

sen.j: - 語学教育 『怪談』（英）
sen.e: - Active in linguistic education: authored "Kwaidan" (Ghost Stories)
sen.cmt: I believe the original spelling of Hearn's book was "Kwaidan".
sen.e: - Active in linguistic education: authored "Kwaidan" (Ghost Stories)

sen.j: エドワード・S・モース（Edward S.Morse 1838-1925）
sen.cmt: I have added the note on nationality here in this line, as per my recommendation. From here on, if this is the only change I have made, I will continue to write "ok" instead of mentioning every time I change the position of the note on nationality.
スペースを修正しました。

sen.j: - 生物学 大森貝塚の発見（米）
sen.e: Biology: discovery of Omori Shell Mounds (USA)
- Biology: discovered the Omori Shell Mounds
- Biology: discovered the Omori Shell Mounds

sen.j: ウイリアム・スミス・クラーク
- 札幌農学校（現北海道大学）初代教頭（米）
sen.e: The first vice-principal at Sapporo Agricultural School (now Hokkaido University) (USA)
- Served as the first vice-principal at Sapporo Agricultural School (now Hokkaido University)
- Served as the first vice-principal at Sapporo Agricultural School (now Hokkaido University)

sen.j: バジル・ホール・チェンバレン
- 語学教育 『古事記』の英訳（英）
sen.e: Linguistic education: translation of "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) into English (UK)
- Active in linguistic education: translated "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) into English
- Active in linguistic education: translated "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) into English

sen.j: ラファエル・フォン・ケーベル (Raphael von Koeber 1848-1923)
sen.cmt: スペースを修正しました。

sen.j: - 哲学 （露）
フィクトール・ホルツ (Viktor Holtz)
- 多科目教育 （独）
sen.e: - Active in education in various fields
- Active in education in various fields

sen.j: エミール・ハウスクネヒト (Emil Hausknecht)
- 教育学 （独）
アリス・メイベル・ベーコン（Alice Mabel Bacon）
- 女子教育 （米）

tit.e: A note on the definition of "oyatoi"
A note on the definition of 'oyatoi'
tit.cmt: クォーツを修正しました。

sen.j: 「御雇（おやとい）」とは（とくに外国人に限らず）武家でない身分の者を、その専門技芸において幕府の「御用」に徴用することを指した。
sen.e: Oyatoi' refers to the requisition of someone who does not belong to the samurai family for his/her special skills/knowledge for the purpose of bakufu's 'choyo' (official business).
"Oyatoi" refers to the hiring of someone who does not belong to a samurai family for his or her special skills or knowledge in order to accomplish the bakufu's official business.

Oyatoi' refers to the hiring of someone (unnecessary to be a foreigner) who does not belong to a samurai family for his or her special skills or knowledge in order to accomplish the bakufu's 'goyo' (official business).
sen.cmt: クォーツを修正しました。（とくに外国人に限らず）を補いました。「御用」'goyo' を補い、修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸期後半になって諸外国の動向が伝わって来るにつけ、武士である幕臣だけではさまざまな専門分野に対応できなかった。
sen.e: When Japan became aware of movements of the foreign countries at the end of the Edo period, they realized that Shogun's retainers alone, who were samurai, could not handle various specialistic fields.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: In the latter half of the Edo period, as the Japanese became aware of the trends affecting foreign countries, it became clear that the Shogun's samurai retainers would not be able to master the bewildering array of specialized fields by themselves.

In the latter half of the Edo period, as the Japanese became aware of the trends affecting foreign countries, it became clear that the Shogun's samurai retainers would not be able to master the bewildering array of specialized fields by themselves.

sen.j: そのため、一般民のなかから専門に秀でたとくに優れた人材を募り、この需要に充てたものである。
sen.e: Therefore, they employed talented non-samurai people to meet this demand.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Therefore, the government began to employ especially talented non-samurai commoners in order to meet the new needs facing them.
Therefore, the government began to employ especially talented non-samurai commoners in order to meet the new needs facing them.

sen.j: しかし幕府の側からすると、身分としてはあくまでも「御雇い」であり、臨時雇用の色合いの濃い立場の低い扱いではあった。
sen.e: However, from the point of view of bakufu, these employees were of 'oyatoi' (hired) status, and as such, their position was characteristically low as temporary employees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: However, from the point of view of the bakufu, these employees were and would always remain of 'oyatoi' (hired) status, and as such, their social position was fully as low as that of temporary employees.

However, from the point of view of the bakufu, these employees were and would always remain of 'oyatoi' (hired) status, and as such, their social position was fully as low as that of temporary employees.

sen.j: しかしなかには能力と功績が認められると正規の幕臣として取り立てられ、武家として称氏（氏姓、苗字を名乗ること）・帯刀・世襲が許される場合もあった。
sen.e: Some of them, however, received recognition for their ability and achievements, and were promoted to the status of proper retainers who were allowed to have family names and to carry swords as well as the tradition of heredity.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Some of these hirees, however, did earn recognition for their abilities and achievements, and were promoted to the status of full retainers and granted family names, allowed to carry two swords, and given hereditary rights to their status.

Some of these hirees, however, did earn recognition for their abilities and achievements, and were promoted to the status of full retainers and granted family names, allowed to carry swords, and given hereditary rights to their status.
sen.cmt: two swords→swords と修正しました。
